channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Hear from people in Iran and Israel as the countries continue to exchange airstrikes
item.description: People in Iran and Israel share their experiences as airstrikes ordered by the leadership of the two countries continue.

item.title: What the Israel-Iran conflict means for the wider region
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks with journalist Kim Ghattas in Beirut about how far the Israel-Iran war could spread and whether other Middle East powers are bracing for a wider conflict.

item.title: European diplomats begin effort to end conflict between Iran and Israel
item.description: A diplomacy effort is underway to end the war between Iran and Israel after a week of fighting. European diplomats are set to hold nuclear talks with their Iranian counterpart on Friday in Geneva.

item.title: Palestinians in Gaza risk their lives to get food as hunger increases
item.description: Gaza has receded from headlines as the conflict between Iran and Israel escalates. But in past week, hundreds of Palestinians have been killed in Gaza, many trying to get food, officials said.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Appeals court backs Trump's control of the California National Guard for now, divisions grow among Trump supporters over Iran, EU ministers undertake diplomatic effort to end Iran-Israel conflict.

item.title: Director Danny Boyle discusses his new movie '28 Years Later'
item.description: NPR talks to Danny Boyle about "28 Years Later," the latest film in his post-apocalyptic horror franchise. It takes place nearly three decades after a zombie virus escaped from a medical research lab.

item.title: How inflation is impacting restaurants across the U.S.
item.description: Inflation has pumped up food prices for consumers at the grocery store and for restaurants. NPR speaks with restaurant owners across the U.S. who sell regional classics to see how they are faring.

item.title: A former DOGE employee gives his account of working for the operation
item.description: What did the Department of Government Efficiency actually accomplish under Elon Musk? And what might change now that Musk is out? One former DOGE worker is going public and sharing what he learned.

item.title: Why many sets of siblings succeed at the highest levels of sport
item.description: An English soccer player this week followed in his brother's footsteps by debuting for an elite German club. NPR looks at why so many sets of siblings make it to the highest levels in sport.

item.title: Divisions grow among Trump supporters over possible U.S. strikes on Iran
item.description: President Trump says he'll decide in the next two weeks whether launch military strikes against Iran. Meanwhile, the conflict is creating divisions among some of Trump's most vocal supporters.
